discussion_comments.comment_body:
Checking my understanding:

For a provider implementation, is this an advisory/optional limit or a best-effort/required limit?

In other words: is the provider responsible for making a best-effort attempt to send no more than `limit` events? I want to say "yes, the provider is responsible for best-effort."
We include the limit as an fyi for the provider (perhaps to save it from overfetching), but if the provider does not adhere to it, we still enforce that limit in core.

Checking my assumptions:

Is it completely the provider's decision re: whether or not to return `resource_object`? Possibly via information in the list config, as defined in the list config schema?

Or do we want the request message to have an explicit `include` (or similar) field that is not schema-dependent?

The current idea is to have an attribute in the config (maybe something like `include_resource`) and, if that field is set, the provider should include the `resource_object`.

Should this be made more explicit with an additional field in the proto request (outside the config)? I imagine that having a field at protocol level removes any ambiguity
yes, if resource data is optional, we should probably directly include whether it's requested or not in the request.
If we want that attribute standardized, then perhaps it should be in the proto definition

If it is in the proto file, what does it mean to the sdk/framework when the attribute is set? Would the sdk invalidate a provider response that does not include the resource despite it being requested for, or is the attribute simply a suggestion?

> If it is in the proto file, what does it mean to the sdk/framework when the attribute is set? Would the sdk invalidate a provider response that does not include the resource despite it being requested for, or is the attribute simply a suggestion?

I imagine the SDK/Framework would simply pass this along to the provider implementation, without inspecting the response.

We _could_ raise a "provider implementation error" if the attribute is set & the returned resource is absent. I don't see a lot of value in that; open to changing my opinion on it, though.
I will add a `include_resource_object` field to the request

I don't know if we want `oneof` here, doesn't that preclude returning both? Terraform has typically assumed there will always be both a result and a diagnostic in every response. While `ListResource` may not require a result with an error like `ApplyResourceChange` does, but there may still be warnings included with a valid result.

> This means that we cannot return a single error without the additional fields 

This is what is typical for other RPCs, so I would also assume it is okay.

Would this not imply that they cannot have both resource and module mapping? Why would we want to restrict that? They may potentially want to select only a few resources from a certain module, and all from the other.

You can't put repeated or map fields into a `oneof`. In my suggestion both the resource and module mappings are contained within the nested mapping - there are maps inside it. Then a more complicated mapping could follow in the `oneof` later that also entirely contains all the mapping information for that approach.
I added a comment directly on the commit: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/commit/bd6c0b5b1bc1fd70192ac8e0ee920d219a409fa2#r152967523
